title: Problems extending BQ to higher dimensions + more complex integrals
body:
Hi,

Speaking to Neil he said this would be a good place to post a technical question. It is more about my lack of knowledge rather than a software issue, so if you would like it posted else where let me know :)

I have been playing around with Bayesian Quadrature in emukit (and using GPy to build my emulator). I have two questions

**(1) Extending to High Dimensions with 'ARD' kernels.**

I follow your worked example for the 1D_Hennig function. This works great! For my application I have a 4 dimesnional input space, so I have build a GP model in GPy

```
kernel = GPy.kern.RBF(input_dim=4,ARD=True)
m = GPy.models.GPRegression(X,Y,kernel)
m.optimize(messages=True)
```

When I try and do BQ I get an error

```
/usr/local/lib/python3.7/site-packages/emukit/quadrature/kernels/quadrature_rbf.py in qKq(self)
     74         erf_term = erf(diff_bounds_scaled) * diff_bounds_scaled * np.sqrt(np.pi)
     75 
---> 76         return np.float(prefac * (exp_term + erf_term).prod())
     77 
     78     # the following methods are gradients of a quadrature kernel

TypeError: only size-1 arrays can be converted to Python scalars
```

This is becuase I am using ARD Squared Exponential Kernel. Is there a way around this? With some digging in your code base I can't see an example or a different class to use. Or do I need to hack it, by rescaling my problem in each of the dimensions? Then retraining an isotropic kernel?

**(2) BQ for more complex integral.**

In the application I am looking at I actually want to do a more complex integral so if f(x) is my integrand which is expensive to compute, I also have a functional r(x) ( in my case a multivariant Gaussian) which is fast to compute, I want to do BQ on 

I = \int f(x)r(x)dx

This is the setting laid out by O'Hagan in his BQ paper. Is there an example of this?

Thanks in advance for your help!

Best

Tim Dodwell
Turing & Exeter
